I have ZERO confidence in "President Trump" to handle this national security crisis. It needs careful deliberation. He is an imbecile fundamentally unfit for office. We will pay a high price for voting him into office. We can thank the millions who fell for his con to vote for him to put us in this situation. Clinton, on the other hand, would have been eminently qualified.

Based on campaign events many Americans voted for Trump because of his promise to make better deals, and the possibility that he might adopt a bilateral approach via direct negotiations with North Korea should not be ruled out. We long ago developed the nuclear capacity to destroy the human race via nuclear weapons, so that isn't new, and our race has always been engaged in violent behavior. Maybe a really, really good deal, the best! is what we're going to get-- it would run counter to history, but the ability to solve problems with a " better deal" is what we were promised.

If I remember correctly, former Pres. Clinton had an agreement with North Korea where we or allied nations were supplying needed food or grain. North Korea was a signer of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Agreement and there were nuclear inspectors on the ground then. When the Bush Administration took over they dismantled the Clinton Agreement. The NK withdrew from the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Agreement and pushed out the inspectors. NK had its first nuclear test in 2006 while Bush was president. Seems Obama did little while NK continued its program.
Pres. Trump said he would talk to North Korea while he was campaigning. Is it worth a try? But I would suggest the uproar against Trump using diplomacy would be deafening.

I have to say, one of the few things North Korea is 100 percent correct about is that they need nuclear weapons. Their policy on that has been 100 percent validated. Saddam Hussein and Gaddafi believed they could get by without WMDs. WMDs are actually a very important part of contemporary peace. That is why we, the USA, have so many of them. It creates absolute military peace within our borders and some way beyond.

North Korea also has peace, of sorts. Peace is created by the promise of orderly and devastating force. These is nothing we can realistically achieve here. North Korean regime won this argument.
Sweden has peace...
Sweden basks under our nuclear umbrella.
for 200 years?

The military thinking described here terrifies me. The U.S., perhaps because of its size and inward looking nature, never seems to have had a good grasp of the interrelated nature of global politics and how seemingly small actions can lead to a terrible harvest many years later. Reagan's bombing of two Libyan cities, a violation of international law, in response to a bomb in a Berlin nightclub that killed two U.S servicemen, didn't just punish an isolated rogue state, it unleashed a wave of hatred against the U.S. across the Arab world that would produce terrible reverberations many years later. Obama's adoption of the drone program, arguably another violation of international law, that has killed many civilians in the process, has further inflamed Anti-American fervour in highly delicate regions and, I would suggest, greatly increased the danger to U.S. national security.

China is far more vulnerable to North Korea than the U.S. But China is also threatened by the U.S. The last thing the world needs is an escalation of tensions between the U.S. and China, yet that seems to be the direction the U.S. is resolutely marching in because it has always taken such a short term and highly blinkered approach to foreign policy.

I suspect Russia is perhaps the greatest danger to the U.S. but this danger is masked. No doubt the Russians are highly enjoying the growth of tensions between the U.S. and North Korea and, by extension, China, as the Russians wait for opportunity.

The news that various types of pre-emptive strikes were and are being considered by Presidents Obama and Trump are as alarming as any news about North Korea's missile capabilities.  Any such attempt could well restart the Korean War and result in mass casualties on the Korean peninsula, again.  Our efforts to prevent the North from gaining nuclear and missile technology have failed despite earnest efforts by the last three administrations (not including the current one).  The only answer is accommodation.  The assurance of mutual destruction is a powerful inducement towards agreeing on ways to de-escalate the threat, and eventual disarmament.  It worked during the Cold War, albeit over many decades, and is the only intelligent way forward here.

Some commenters have asked that we cast aside our political differences with this Administration, and support him in facing the grave nuclear threat that North Korea poses. These comments assume that we have a president who is of sound mind, and acts with deliberation.

If that were true, I'd wholeheartedly support him. But what these commenters are really asking me to do is to support someone who could easily rush the planet headlong into a nuclear winter.

What we should be doing, instead, is to support every effort to have this president removed from office. Quite simply, he, himself, is an existential threat to all of us.

I have no doubt that Generals Mattis, Kelly and now McMaster will guide the foreign policy in a steady manner . Obama listened to none of his advisers and made most of his foreign policy decisions solo- see Syria, Libya, Iran, Israel , Cuba and of course the subject of this op ed, North Korea.
I'm sure Kim Jong-un is with you on this.

We either allow North Korea to have nukes capable of threatening and hitting our allies and the U.S. or we don't. Given that allowing such nuclear capability would be an unacceptable situation, there is ONLY one government we can trust to do the right thing. China will do nothing and cannot be trusted, Russia cannot be be trusted- that leaves us, nobody else.

Cyber actions cause North Korea an itch and little more, it requires direct action. Sanctions will have little effect, the NK regime are well used to sanctions and the NK people are used having little to nothing, for their majority it is all they know.

We must demand the immediate return of the student they currently have imprisoned under sentence of 15 years hard labor on ridiculous charges, and we must demand that NK immediately descale all nuclear development. We must upgrade our intelligence and watch for a nuclear accident, especially at facilities when Kim is conducting inspections on-site.

We must be ready to offer assistance and aid to NK on the back of a nuclear accident that has taken-out their leadership, and we must work with the new leadership to assure the world that NK has embarked on a program of removing the evils of nuclear from their land.

Military conflict is coming sooner or later. It's our choice, but it's coming. The key is to avoid actual war. I know, I know... I don't like it either, but NK and Kim are an existential threat to our planet, and cyber simply does not cut the mustard.

So, Bernie was right. Anybody remember the primary debate when Chuck Todd asked him which was the greatest threat to our security: Russia, Iran or North Korea and Bernie answered North Korea?

Chuck Todd then proceeded to inform Hillary Clinton that the Secretary of Defense had said that Russia was our biggest threat (he'd saved that info for her) so of course she agreed. They were obviously trying to make her look informed and make Bernie look uninformed. He was sneered at over this in much of the mainstream media the next day.

I agreed with Bernie then and it sure is gratifying to see him vindicated now. It was infuriating to see the way he was brushed off by the MSM, including this publication, throughout the primaries.

Eight years ago, given the backdrop of 2008 market collapse, an impressionable President sought to fashion a China friendly policy, with talk of G-2, and carving out of respective spheres of geo-political influence.

Likewise, it is early days for Trump Presidency, and on international matters, the usual tactics of beginning with politically diametrically opposite approach and cover ground towards political center is not affordable. A policy of bipartisan consensus on these global policy matters is crucial for success.

Policy on N Korea is a component of policy on China. Whether US needs to work with China to mitigate N Korean missile threat, or deploy a coercive approach is not clear yet. The third option, which previous administration preferred, be it Cyber war or Drone attacks in case of Islamic radical threats; is only an attenuation strategy; at best it kicks the can further down the road.

Neither Bush nor Obama took measures to control the crazed Kim dynasty. Yes it's a difficult task.  We fail to understand that both Koreas  see the US as the power preventing their unification.  We should allow them to resolve the issue peacefully as most in the South desire.  Once resolved, North Korea will forget about aiming their nukes at the US.

The problem is there is nothing at stake for the Kim family (the only people they care about) in a nuclear fist fight, they would be assured of a safe bunker to hide in, whereas even a single, errant, nuclear warhead that misses Seoul by 50 miles is still catastrophic for South Korea.

The NYT reported that the top echelon of the Chinese Communist Party has combined personal assets equivalent to the GNP of Sweden; that's why the Chinese won't do anything stupid in the world, because their personal fortunes would be wiped out as well.

That's what the US needs to do, let the Kim family grow rich by building up Pyongyang so that the capital cannot afford to be destroyed because their personal fortune, not worth billions, would go up in smokes as well.

We turn a blind eye to the Chinese Communist Party's personal gains, so what's the difference in dealing with the Kim family the same way. Once their personal fortunes are tied in to the world market, they have no choice but to drift towards the world market model.

The difference is that North Korea doesn't want to open up to the rest of the world.  That's why Kim killed his uncle and brother.  Both were friendly with China and wanted to open up the economy like China did.

Reading reading the comments on this article by NYT readers, a group, I assume, of intelligent consumers, is unnerving. It makes me hope, pray, that we have the most prudent military leaders who know the real effects of destructive war. The array of options from "take them out now," to blame Cheney, etc. is truly demonstrative of non-thoughtful analysis and response and must, I am afraid, also represent the voices of those in charge of the decisions.
What would happen, (it may have already), if the US, allies and China, were to quietly tell the N. Koreans that any aggressive action would be met with total anhiliation from all sides? It has been called mutual deterrence for about 70 years.

Both to keep the world safe, & to free the slave states the SovUnion kept adding. Then also we should have helped China, when it asked, for help after WW2. We helped the aggressors (Japan), other of the ruined Asian states, like South Korea (Russia grabbed N.Korea & later China). By saying no to countries like China & N.Korea & N.Vietnam, we set this scenario up. But let Russia keep any country they traveled over to take down Germany.

Since you give no ideas for these severe ramifications, I figure it would be more of the same wishy washy, must not make them upset, types we have used over & over since WW2? Our forays into "police actions" actually just prove my theory. Even with the deaths of our people, we have not gone in to any enemy country with the will to win, since WW2. Letting hundreds of thousands of our boys die is fine. But, must not upset the country attacking our allies.

I think, that more than ever, North Korea is open to negotiation. The North understands that a some point China will give up on them, especially if the Trump administration uses it as a bargaining chip for negotiation about Taiwan or the South China Sea.

The assassination of Kim Jong-Nam is a way for his brother Kim Jong-un to get rid of a potential adversary, a moderate who in case of successful negotiation or coup d'etat, would have been an acceptable replacement.

"It was the dream of Kim Il-sung, the country’s founder, who bitterly remembered the American threats to use nuclear weapons against the North during the Korean War."

This is a bit of an alternative fact. I don't dispute that the Kims are among the world's worsts tyrants. But the bitterness among not only Kim Il-sung and an entire generation of North Koreans really comes from the carpet bombing and resultant mass slaughter conducted by America during the war. It is a war crime never acknowledged -- much less understood -- by America. It is also part of the reason the Kims have remained in power.

There is no way China could fear the "heavy" U.S. troop presence in South Korea. It's not that big, and China's land-based military strength is very strong.  If anything, it fears a conflict with the North Korean conventional forces, which might occur if the wrong regime occupies the resultant power vacuum. There's a reason the U.S. won't sign landmine treaties, and it's the Korean DMZ.
